item.dc:creator: @TheHolyGrail TheHolyGrail
item.description:
@TheHolyGrail wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:15, topic:459580”]There are reasons it FORCES you to add try blocks in some cases, and it’s because exceptions can be thrown, no matter how ‘good’ or well written the code is. Your logic is flawed – there are two main reasons to print stack traces, one being debugging like you said, to fix code. The other however is to fix problems that the code isn’t affecting, for example reader classes detecting a corrupt or mis-formatted file. How would you know what the problem was without knowing what the exception was? Even though it has nothing to do with the code itself, it’s still a possibility. Whether or not you want the end user to see these exceptions depends on the situation. You don’t always have to print stack traces, but the reason isn’t because ‘the code is written properly’.

Just for future reference.[/quote]I get what your saying. When I program, I think of how it effects the user, and the user would not know what to do with that information. Almost all games and programs in general tell the user an error occured and exit the program, which is essentially what was happening, since the program would exit when an exception is thrown.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

There are reasons it FORCES you to add try blocks in some cases, and it’s because exceptions can be thrown, no matter how ‘good’ or well written the code is. Your logic is flawed – there are two main reasons to print stack traces, one being debugging like you said, to fix code. The other however is to fix problems that the code isn’t affecting, for example reader classes detecting a corrupt or mis-formatted file. How would you know what the problem was without knowing what the exception was? Even though it has nothing to do with the code itself, it’s still a possibility. Whether or not you want the end user to see these exceptions depends on the situation. You don’t always have to print stack traces, but the reason isn’t because ‘the code is written properly’.

Just for future reference.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @TheHolyGrail TheHolyGrail
item.description:
@TheHolyGrail wrote:

[quote=“Whackatre, post:13, topic:459580”][quote author=TheHolyGrail link=topic=562498.msg4101916#msg4101916 date=1347586847]
If you read what I said,

Anything could cause an exception, but, if you read it, it’s obvious it won’t.

This is all about me not printing stack traces. I said the reason I’m not printing the stack traces is because the likeliness of an exception occuring for those particular instances is relatively low, and, if one were to occur, it would not be an exception caused by the code, but an exception with outer forces. Also, learn some manners. That may be how you talk to your mother, but treat strangers with some respect.
[/quote]
which is exactly the reason why you should print out stack traces.

[quote author=TheHolyGrail link=topic=562498.msg4101875#msg4101875 date=1347583457]

[quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=562498.msg4101764#msg4101764 date=1347577377]

Why do you have blank catch blocks? Why not at least print the stack trace during an exception?
[/quote]Because an exception will not be thrown. If you read the code, you would see nothing I am doing would cause an error for those particular exceptions.

yes you are
[/quote]Look kid, I know my own code. Stop trying to look like you know what the hell you’re talking about. Sorry, but you flamers are starting to piss me off.

lol…[/quote]Actually no, the reason stack traces are printed is to debug code. And about the kid thing, we all lose our tempers at times, I’m not perfect.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

Look retard asshole cunt faggot, methods like BufferedReader.readLine and and the Robot constructor throw exceptions when certain unwanted behavior occurs. In the case of Robot and the AWTException, it’s thrown if the Robot implementation can’t acquire what it needs to send input to the system. Before you decide to be a whiny bitch asshole, please verify all information you are about to post.

Read full topic
